div.p: To Dr Kirk H.M's V. Consul Zanzibar.

I write a mere note at present as I
expect to send letters from Ujiji in a month
or two and the party that takes this is still
going west. The Arabs are very much
more careful not to frighten the people
than we ever were, messages and
presents are sent on ahead and explanations
given till it is tiresome to listen to the
details. The bearer of this Leyd hi Ali
is anxious to be introduced to you and as
he has been extremely kind to me I can
recommend him as a very different sort of
man from the cruel Kilwa traders who
have strewed the road to Nyassa with human
bones; I have been with this party upwards
of four months and whatever they may be
elsewhere their conduct has been good during
that period, this man has been kind
and very hospitable to me personally
so
so you may look on him as one of my
friends. I hope you keep your health?
Having no medicine mine is poorly when
not travelling. You will see the worthy
who lost our medicine box, his head is of
the shape always figured by Grant, he
has run away twice, had no complaint
to make of me, but to his companions
said he did not like work, prefers begging
from the Arab slaves in exchange for bringing
fire wood and water. There was some
pleasure totoo in bringing me to a stand still
I was so short handed. Fancy him
lying down in the jungle and having us
shooting, firing for him while he rested.
I had a bad lot this time - they nearly
all took after the wretched sepoys.
